trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Use Copy Activity in an Azure Data Factory Pipeline
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Use Copy Activity in an Azure Data Factory Pipeline

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use Copy Activity in an Azure Data Factory pipeline that to copy data from an Azure blob to an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use Copy Activity in an Azure Data Factory pipeline that to copy data from an Azure blob to an Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Copy data from an Azure blob to Azure SQL
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Copy data from an Azure blob to Azure SQL

trans-unit.source: The tutorial in this article helps you quickly get started with using the Azure Data Factory service.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial in this article helps you quickly get started with using the Azure Data Factory service.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will create an Azure data factory and create a pipeline in the data factory to copy data from an Azure blob storage to an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will create an Azure data factory and create a pipeline in the data factory to copy data from an Azure blob storage to an Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: For a detailed overview of the Data Factory service, see the <link><linkText>Introduction to Azure Data Factory[data-factory-introduction]</linkText><title></title></link> article .
trans-unit.target: For a detailed overview of the Data Factory service, see the <link><linkText>Introduction to Azure Data Factory[data-factory-introduction]</linkText><title></title></link> article .

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites for the tutorial
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites for the tutorial

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have a subscription, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have a subscription, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: See the <link><linkText>Free Trial[azure-free-trial]</linkText><title></title></link> article for details.
trans-unit.target: See the <link><linkText>Free Trial[azure-free-trial]</linkText><title></title></link> article for details.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage Account.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage Account.

trans-unit.source: You will use the blob storage as a source data store in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will use the blob storage as a source data store in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: if you don't have an Azure storage account, see the <link><linkText>Create a storage account[data-factory-create-storage]</linkText><title></title></link> article for steps to create one.
trans-unit.target: if you don't have an Azure storage account, see the <link><linkText>Create a storage account[data-factory-create-storage]</linkText><title></title></link> article for steps to create one.

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: You will use an Azure SQL database as a destination data store in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will use an Azure SQL database as a destination data store in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an Azure SQL database that you can use in the tutorial, See <link><linkText>How to create and configure an Azure SQL Database[data-factory-create-sql-database]</linkText><title></title></link> to create one.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an Azure SQL database that you can use in the tutorial, See <link><linkText>How to create and configure an Azure SQL Database[data-factory-create-sql-database]</linkText><title></title></link> to create one.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server 2012/2014 or Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server 2012/2014 or Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: You will use SQL Server Management Studio or Visual Studio to create a sample database and to view the result data in the database.
trans-unit.target: You will use SQL Server Management Studio or Visual Studio to create a sample database and to view the result data in the database.

trans-unit.source: Collect account name and account key for your Azure storage account
trans-unit.target: Collect account name and account key for your Azure storage account

trans-unit.source: You will need the account name and account key of your Azure storage account to do this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will need the account name and account key of your Azure storage account to do this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Note down the account name and account key for your Azure storage account by following the instructions below:
trans-unit.target: Note down the account name and account key for your Azure storage account by following the instructions below:

trans-unit.source: Login to the <link><linkText>Azure Preview Portal[azure-preview-portal]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Login to the <link><linkText>Azure Preview Portal[azure-preview-portal]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click BROWSE hub on the left and select Storage Accounts.
trans-unit.target: Click BROWSE hub on the left and select Storage Accounts.

trans-unit.source: In the Storage Accounts blade, select the Azure storage account that you want to use in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In the Storage Accounts blade, select the Azure storage account that you want to use in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In the STORAGE blade, click KEYS tile.
trans-unit.target: In the STORAGE blade, click KEYS tile.

trans-unit.source: In the Manage Keys blade, click copy (image) button next to STORAGE ACCOUNT NAME text box and save/paste it somewhere (for example: in a text file).
trans-unit.target: In the Manage Keys blade, click copy (image) button next to STORAGE ACCOUNT NAME text box and save/paste it somewhere (for example: in a text file).

trans-unit.source: Repeat the previous step to copy or note down the PRIMARY ACCESS KEY.
trans-unit.target: Repeat the previous step to copy or note down the PRIMARY ACCESS KEY.

trans-unit.source: Close all the blades by clicking X.
trans-unit.target: Close all the blades by clicking X.

trans-unit.source: Collect server name, database name, and user account for your Azure SQL database
trans-unit.target: Collect server name, database name, and user account for your Azure SQL database

trans-unit.source: You will need the names of Azure SQL server, database, and user to do this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will need the names of Azure SQL server, database, and user to do this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Note down names of server, database, and user for your Azure SQL database by following the instructions below:
trans-unit.target: Note down names of server, database, and user for your Azure SQL database by following the instructions below:

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Preview Portal, click BROWSE on the left and select SQL databases.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Preview Portal, click BROWSE on the left and select SQL databases.

trans-unit.source: In the SQL databases blade, select the database that you want to use in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In the SQL databases blade, select the database that you want to use in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Note down the database name.
trans-unit.target: Note down the database name.

trans-unit.source: In the SQL DATABASE blade, click PROPERTIES tile.
trans-unit.target: In the SQL DATABASE blade, click PROPERTIES tile.

trans-unit.source: Note down the values for SERVER NAME and SERVER ADMIN LOGIN.
trans-unit.target: Note down the values for SERVER NAME and SERVER ADMIN LOGIN.

trans-unit.source: Close all the blades by clicking X.
trans-unit.target: Close all the blades by clicking X.

trans-unit.source: Allow Azure services to access the Azure SQL server
trans-unit.target: Allow Azure services to access the Azure SQL server

trans-unit.source: Ensure that Allow access to Azure services setting turned ON for your Azure SQL server so that the Data Factory service can access your Azure SQL server.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that Allow access to Azure services setting turned ON for your Azure SQL server so that the Data Factory service can access your Azure SQL server.

trans-unit.source: To verify and turn this setting on, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To verify and turn this setting on, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click BROWSE hub on the left and click SQL servers.
trans-unit.target: Click BROWSE hub on the left and click SQL servers.

trans-unit.source: Select your server, and click SETTINGS on the SQL SERVER blade.
trans-unit.target: Select your server, and click SETTINGS on the SQL SERVER blade.

trans-unit.source: In the SETTINGS blade, click Firewall.
trans-unit.target: In the SETTINGS blade, click Firewall.

trans-unit.source: In the Firewall settings blade, click ON for Allow access to Azure services.
trans-unit.target: In the Firewall settings blade, click ON for Allow access to Azure services.

trans-unit.source: Close all the blades by clicking X.
trans-unit.target: Close all the blades by clicking X.

trans-unit.source: Prepare Azure Blob Storage and Azure SQL Database for the tutorial
trans-unit.target: Prepare Azure Blob Storage and Azure SQL Database for the tutorial

trans-unit.source: Now, prepare your Azure blob storage and Azure SQL database for the tutorial by performing the following steps:
trans-unit.target: Now, prepare your Azure blob storage and Azure SQL database for the tutorial by performing the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Launch Notepad, paste the following text, and save it as emp.txt to C:\ADFGetStarted folder on your hard drive.
trans-unit.target: Launch Notepad, paste the following text, and save it as emp.txt to C:\ADFGetStarted folder on your hard drive.

trans-unit.source: Use tools such as Azure Storage Explorer to create the adftutorial container and to upload the emp.txt file to the container.
trans-unit.target: Use tools such as Azure Storage Explorer to create the adftutorial container and to upload the emp.txt file to the container.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Storage Explorer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Storage Explorer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Use the following SQL script to create the emp table in your Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Use the following SQL script to create the emp table in your Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: If you have SQL Server 2012/2014 installed on your computer: follow instructions from Step 2: Connect to SQL Database of the Managing Azure SQL Database using SQL Server Management Studio[sql-management-studio] article to connect to your Azure SQL server and run the SQL script.
trans-unit.target: If you have SQL Server 2012/2014 installed on your computer: follow instructions from Step 2: Connect to SQL Database of the Managing Azure SQL Database using SQL Server Management Studio[sql-management-studio] article to connect to your Azure SQL server and run the SQL script.

trans-unit.source: Note that this article uses the release management portal (http://manage.windowsazure.com), not the preview portal (http://portal.azure.com), to configure firewall for an Azure SQL server.
trans-unit.target: Note that this article uses the release management portal (http://manage.windowsazure.com), not the preview portal (http://portal.azure.com), to configure firewall for an Azure SQL server.

trans-unit.source: If you have Visual Studio 2013 installed on your computer: in the Azure Preview Portal, click BROWSE hub on the left, click SQL servers, select your database, and click Open in Visual Studio button on toolbar to connect to your Azure SQL server and run the script.
trans-unit.target: If you have Visual Studio 2013 installed on your computer: in the Azure Preview Portal, click BROWSE hub on the left, click SQL servers, select your database, and click Open in Visual Studio button on toolbar to connect to your Azure SQL server and run the script.

trans-unit.source: If your client is not allowed to access the Azure SQL server, you will need to configure firewall for your Azure SQL server to allow access from your machine (IP Address).
trans-unit.target: If your client is not allowed to access the Azure SQL server, you will need to configure firewall for your Azure SQL server to allow access from your machine (IP Address).

trans-unit.source: See the article above for steps to configure the firewall for your Azure SQL server.
trans-unit.target: See the article above for steps to configure the firewall for your Azure SQL server.

trans-unit.source: Do the following:
trans-unit.target: Do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click <link><linkText>Using Data Factory Editor</linkText><title></title></link> link at the top to perform the tutorial by using Data Factory Editor, which is part of the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Click <link><linkText>Using Data Factory Editor</linkText><title></title></link> link at the top to perform the tutorial by using Data Factory Editor, which is part of the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Click <link><linkText>Using PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link> link at the top to perform the tutorial by using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Click <link><linkText>Using PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link> link at the top to perform the tutorial by using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Click <link><linkText>Using Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link> link at the top to perform the tutorial by using Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: Click <link><linkText>Using Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link> link at the top to perform the tutorial by using Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Send Feedback
trans-unit.target: Send Feedback

trans-unit.source: We would really appreciate your feedback on this article.
trans-unit.target: We would really appreciate your feedback on this article.

trans-unit.source: Please take a few minutes to submit your feedback via <link><linkText>email</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Please take a few minutes to submit your feedback via <link><linkText>email</linkText><title></title></link>.
